Well, as I say, I am a professor of landscape archaeology at the University of Exeter.
And my interest in the wetlands around the Severn Estuary goes back to my PhD.
That was a study of both sides of the estuary and it looked at the changing ways that human
communities exploited the rich natural resources of these wetlands.
And then gradually started to intensify how they used the wetlands.
Rather than just hunting and fishing, they started grazing their livestock,
in banking the land, using it for arable farming and so on.
And I looked at that over the Roman and the medieval periods.
Then I got the job doing the grant levels historic landscape study that we talked about.

But actually, I think my work hopefully shows that if you were just like a peasant farmer ploughing a few fields and tending a few sheep, not a lot actually changed.
So I spent a few years sort of studying that.
So I sort of I tried to move on from wetlands, not because I didn't enjoy studying them, but just because, you know, a typical academic career is about 40 years.
And I don't think many academics want to spend 40 years studying exactly the same thing.
A change is always good, isn't it, I think?
Yeah, but one of the reasons why I've so enjoyed my involvement in the Living Levels project is that it has brought me back to a landscape that I studied so intensively for two years.
For two years, that was my whole life.
Yeah, yeah.

really new and a really sort of innovative concept.
The archaeologists shouldn't just be grubbing about in the dirt, but archaeologists
should be appreciating the historic importance of the landscape all around us.

I found out about the cycle of cleaning out the ditches.
It's only the major water courses that you would have cleaned out every year.
Then you'd have this cycle of cleaning the minor reams perhaps every three years.
The field boundaries, a farmer might just clean out two field boundaries a year.
They might have something like almost a 30-year cycle, some of them.
Of course, that's how you get the difference in vegetation in these ditches because you get these different times.
Neville told me all about that.

Can I just ask you quickly about the drainage?
So you would be looking at that evidence of that as well in your landscape?
Yeah.
So to me, it seemed terribly complicated.
So how have you managed to work that out?
Is that by referring to the drainage maps?
A lot of it was actually quite obvious just by walking around the landscape talking to Susan Howard all those years ago.
The way that the drainage system works hasn't fundamentally changed for a thousand years.
It's gravity led.
Yeah.
There's not the pumping that you get, for example, on the Somerset levels and have had on the Somerset levels for many hundreds of years.
So it's just a gravity fed system where you know the Monks did.
Yes.
You see that?
That is one of the channels that is designed to take streams flowing off of the uplands across the levels without flooding them.
That deals with that problem.
Yeah.
Then you've got to deal with all the wet stuff falling out of the sky, the rain.
Yeah.
And that's why you have the gripes.
Yeah.
They take their water into the field boundary ditches, the field boundary ditches drain into the reams.
Yeah.
And reams then discharge their waters under the seawall through those tidal sluices.
So it's a very simple system.
Yeah.
It's wonderfully simple.
But it's sophisticated because the land is lower away from the seawall, isn't it?
So it's effectively going up, isn't it?
Well, no, you just have to dig the ditches deeper and deeper as you go towards the coast.
Right.
Yes.
Yeah.
That's the thing.
See, the other feature, which means that it works, is because of the huge tidal range of the seven estuary.
Yeah.
So what basically happens is that when the tide is high, the flap on those tidal gates is foreshut.
So all the water is held in the drainage ditches in the levels.
But then you get this long period when the tide goes down, the tidal gates can open and you then get this very long period when all the water can flow out.
Yeah.
So if you had a much smaller tidal range, those tidal flaps could end up being closed for much longer.
Right.
OK.
Yeah.
They were actually really closed for a relatively short period of the day.
Yeah.
So that's also why this gravity fed system can work, because enough of the water can get out.
Yeah.
Quite quickly.
Do you know the movements of the seven, you know, it's ebbing and flowing and all that.
Is that something that's of interest to landscape archaeologists like you?
It's a natural phenomenon.
Yeah.
Of course, it's instrumental to the wetlands having been created.

Yeah.
Much, much smaller.
Yeah.
